item.title: Foreign aid: PM faces pre-G7 backbench bid to reverse cut
item.description: Senior Tories want the commitment to spend 0.7% of national income on overseas development restored.

item.title: Covid vaccine stickers come to dating apps in UK
item.description: The optional badges will be displayable on dating profiles as part of a government collaboration.

item.title: Abubakar Shekau: Boko Haram leader is dead, says rival militant group
item.description: An audio recording suggests Abubakar Shekau killed himself during a gunfight with a rival group.

item.title: Christopher Kapessa: Mum plans legal action over river death
item.description: Christopher Kapessa, 13, was reportedly pushed into a river by another boy.

item.title: Cricketer Robinson suspended over tweets
item.description: England pace bowler Ollie Robinson will not play in the second Test against New Zealand starting on Thursday.

item.title: Bafta TV Awards honour multi-talented Michaela Coel for I May Destroy You
item.description: She adds a best actress prize to awards for writing and directing her drama I May Destroy You.

item.title: Prince Harry and Meghan announce birth of baby girl
item.description: The Duke and Duchess of Sussex say their daughter, Lilibet, was born on Friday and is "settling in at home".

item.title: Covid-19: Government 'open' to delaying 21 June England lockdown end date
item.description: Matt Hancock says 21 June is a "not before" date for ending England's remaining restrictions.

item.title: Kent council in child migrant legal threat to Home Secretary
item.description: Kent County Council begins legal action against Priti Patel as child migrants overwhelm services.

item.title: David Dushman, last surviving Auschwitz liberator, dies aged 98
item.description: As a 21-year-old Red Army soldier, David Dushman used his tank to mow down the camp's electric fence.

item.title: England 1-0 Romania: Marcus Rashford scores from penalty spot
item.description: England will head into Euro 2020 on the back of six straight wins after a Marcus Rashford penalty secures victory over Romania.

item.title: Stay-at-home holidaymakers warned of summer essentials shortage
item.description: UK importers say they are still waiting on goods stuck on container ships in other parts of the world.

item.title: Rugeley Power Station cooling towers demolished
item.description: More than 2,300 homes will be built on site of former Rugeley Power Station

item.title: The Papers: 'Battle to save 21 June' and a royal 'gran gesture'
item.description: Monday's papers react to a potential delay to the easing of Covid restrictions and the new royal baby.

item.title: Bafta TV Awards: Winners and highlights - Michaela Coel, Diversity, Paul Mescal
item.description: Michaela Coel, Diversity and Paul Mescal were among the winners on British TV's big awards night.

item.title: Bristol 'tornado': Video shows funnel cloud over the city
item.description: The spinning column of wind was filmed by residents in the city on Sunday evening.

item.title: Bafta TV Awards 2021 red carpet in pictures
item.description: Stars get together in person for the most prestigious British ceremony in the industry's calendar.

item.title: Thandiwe Muriu: Standing out in camouflage
item.description: Kenyan photographer Thandiwe Muriu creates striking images that celebrate and challenge her culture.

item.title: 'Children here are free to be who they are'
item.description: More than half of the students at St Patrick's College in Dungannon are "newcomer pupils".

item.title: Greece's islands aim to go 'Covid-free' to welcome back tourists
item.description: Milos is aiming to become a "Covid-free" zone by vaccinating all its residents and workers.

item.title: Toppling Bristol's Edward Colston statue: How do people feel now?
item.description: One year on from the toppling of slaver Edward Colston's statue what impact has it had in Bristol?

item.title: Daniel Ellsberg: The 90-year-old whistleblower tempting prosecution
item.description: Fifty years after he leaked the Pentagon Papers, Daniel Ellsberg says he's made another disclosure.

item.title: Bafta TV Awards: 8 backstage bites from the ceremony
item.description: From a panicked Paul Mescal to Romesh being rumbled, here are the best quotes from the winners' room.

item.title: 'My foggy glasses solution helped me through Covid'
item.description: Alex Wickens explains how a business idea during the pandemic restored his hopes for the future.

item.title: Why Kim Jong-un is waging war on slang, jeans and foreign films
item.description: A sweeping new law makes the smuggling of foreign news, films or drama punishable by death.

item.title: The couple rescuing the house they bought by accident
item.description: Cal Hunter and Claire Segeren wanted a flat in Glasgow but accidentally ended up with a crumbling eyesore 35 miles away.

item.title: 'Clothes are torn, worn out - I can't find work gloves'
item.description: How supply chains can be strengthened to protect against shocks and shortages in the future.

item.title: England turn down chase to grind out draw against New Zealand
item.description: England resist the temptation of a final-day chase against New Zealand, doggedly batting through two sessions to draw the first Test at Lord's.

item.title: French Open 2021: Serena Williams knocked out in fourth round by Elena Rybakina
item.description: Serena Williams' latest bid for a 24th Grand Slam singles title ends with a shock defeat by Elena Rybakina in the French Open fourth round.

item.title: Cantlay wins Memorial Tournament after play-off with Morikawa
item.description: Patrick Cantlay wins the USPGA Memorial Tournament for the second time in three years after prevailing in a play-off with fellow American Collin Morikawa.

item.title: England and New Zealand settle for draw
item.description: Watch highlights as England doggedly bat through the afternoon to secure a draw against New Zealand in the first Test at Lord's.

item.title: England v New Zealand: 'This is a lesson on how not to put a cagoule on'
item.description: The biggest round of applause at Lord's on Sunday goes to a spectator struggling to put his cagoule on!

item.title: What are the rules for travelling to green, amber and red list countries?
item.description: Foreign holidays are now possible, but travellers must follow strict rules on their return.

item.title: UK holidays: When and where can I go... and who with?
item.description: Going abroad has got trickier and people are opting to stay in the UK for their holidays

item.title: Covid: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: Covid-19 rules in Wales are changing - but for many in Scotland the lifting of lockdown has been "paused".

item.title: Lockdown muscle loss: Five ways to get back in shape
item.description: Lockdown inactivity may have left people with weaker muscles - there are simple solutions.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: Over-18s can now have the vaccine in Wales and Northern Ireland, while over-30s can get it in England and Scotland.

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: Covid: How is Europe lifting lockdown restrictions?
item.description: A third Covid wave hit much of Europe hard but now gradually lockdowns are being eased.

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 38 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: Coronavirus: How does the test-and-trace system work?
item.description: Michael Gove was contacted by NHS Test and Trace but is not required to self-isolate

item.title: Travel guide to Spain, Portugal, France and more holiday hotspots
item.description: What you need to know about travelling abroad to Portugal, Spain, Greece, France, Italy and Turkey.

item.title: Covid: What do under-30s need to know about the vaccine?
item.description: The vaccine rollout is now reaching younger adults. What do they need to know about getting jabbed?

item.title: Covid: What refund rights are there for holidays abroad?
item.description: What rights do you have if your holidays plans or rules change?

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: 'Nepal variant': What's the mutation stopping green list trips to Portugal?
item.description: Ministers have raised concerns over a mutation to the Delta variant first identified in India.

item.title: Covid-19: Could a third wave change 21 June plans in England?
item.description: Rising coronavirus cases have called the planned 21 June relaxing of rules in England into question.

item.title: Do social distance rules apply after both vaccine jabs?
item.description: Guidance on hugging close friends and family has being relaxed in England and Scotland.

item.title: Coronavirus: When can we stop wearing face masks or face coverings?
item.description: Rules are relaxing, but masks are still needed in some settings - here's where and why.

item.title: Tokyo Olympic Games: When are they and will they go ahead despite Covid?
item.description: The Tokyo Summer Olympics are due to start in July, despite a surge in Covid cases in Japan.

item.title: Covid: Should I be working from home or going back to the office?
item.description: As lockdown restrictions ease gradually across the UK, what are the rules about returning to work?

item.title: Covid vaccine update: Those that work - and the others on the way
item.description: Covid vaccination campaigns are under way in the UK and across the world.

item.title: Coronavirus: What's the risk of Covid on public transport?
item.description: As UK coronavirus restrictions are relaxed, public transport could become much busier.

item.title: How are eviction rules for renters and landlords changing?
item.description: The eviction ban is ending, but what does that mean?

item.title: The Motherload: How pandemic anger almost destroyed a mums' support group
item.description: Abusive messages from angry mums during lockdown almost caused the founder of The Motherload to close it down.

item.title: The children selling explicit videos on OnlyFans
item.description: British subscription site OnlyFans is failing to prevent underage users from selling and appearing in explicit videos, a BBC investigation has found.

item.title: How Ben Crump became America's go-to police brutality lawyer
item.description: When families lose a loved one in a police shooting, more often than not Ben Crump gets a call. Why is he the go-to man?

item.title: Samantha Azzopardi: Australia's notorious con artist sentenced for child theft
item.description: Authorities are baffled by the "bizarre crime" of a serial con artist who has travelled the world.

item.title: After a 32-year battle for justice, what is Hillsborough's legacy?
item.description: As the collapse of the last criminal trial marks the end of a long legal road, Judith Moritz asks what the legacy of Britainâ€™s worst sports disaster is.
